channel.title: Comments on: Oh, ah-linting I will go

item.title: By: essay corrector
item.dc:creator: essay corrector
item.description: <p>This is a really significant step to be made by someone to become a successful programmer. Hope you will read http://essaycorrector.org/blog/page/16 and find it fascinating!</p>
item.content:encoded: This is a really significant step to be made by someone to become a successful programmer. Hope you will read http://essaycorrector.org/blog/page/16 and find it fascinating!

item.title: By: Keith Strickland
item.dc:creator: Keith Strickland
item.description: <p>As far as JavaScript isn't strongly typed, you can always go down the TypeScript road. This does provide stronger typing to your JavaScript and brings JavaScript more inline with Java/C#. The great thing about it is, once implemented you don't really have to change anything about your existing codebase because TypeScript IS JavaScript, it just adds typings to it. I've been using it for about 6 months now and I love it. You're able to define abstract classes, classes, inheritance, interfaces, enums, etc. which really helps on a large project.</p>
item.content:encoded: As far as JavaScript isn’t strongly typed, you can always go down the TypeScript road. This does provide stronger typing to your JavaScript and brings JavaScript more inline with Java/C#. The great thing about it is, once implemented you don’t really have to change anything about your existing codebase because TypeScript IS JavaScript, it just adds typings to it. I’ve been using it for about 6 months now and I love it. You’re able to define abstract classes, classes, inheritance, interfaces, enums, etc. which really helps on a large project.
